_decoded_content.title: Windows pytest Failures
_decoded_content.description:
There's a number of pytest tests that are skipped for Windows. You can grep the code for this issue number to find them.  (at the time of writing this issue the code is https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/merge_requests/2639 ) 

I think success for this issue is that most of the Windows Tests are passing, and any individual tests that are left marked as "skipped" either have an individual issue in for them or are acceptable to ignore and the reason is put in pytest.

_decoded_content.title: windows: pipx installed meltano can not find meltano dependency example gunicorn
_decoded_content.description:
### What is the current *bug* behavior?
pipx installed meltano is not able to find dependent packages like gunicorn.  



### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
I am expecting pipx meltano to be able to find dependent packages like an it does in a manually created python enviroment with pip installed meltano.



### Steps to reproduce
pipx meltano FileNotFound steps
```
pipx install meltano
meltano init meltano-demo
cd meltano-demo
meltano ui
```
python venv pip meltano file found ran and crashes on ModuleNotFoundError
```
python -m venv .\.venv\meltano
.\.venv\meltano\Scripts\Activate.ps1
pip install meltano
cd meltano-demo
meltano ui
```




### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
![image](/uploads/e854f517695d0bb0e5f56fe21b45ab8b/image.png)

![image](/uploads/f7692de557c40c2ce830d05a4178d258/image.png)



### Possible fixes
The fix is that in the meltano_invoker it searches for exact file name in the active python environment but in windows these files have a .exe at the end so the file search fails.  The command is run hoping it is in the path but the only path pipx give it to the users .local\bin that does not contain all the dependent packages so the application doesn't run. 



### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

_decoded_content.title: Meltano UI does not work on Windows (Gunicorn is incompatible)
_decoded_content.description:
Gunicorn is used in Meltano UI, and simply does not support Windows.

We could evaluate similar alternatives to Gunicorn which would support Windows, and thereby allow windows users to also run `meltano ui`. One such option is Waitress:

- https://betterprogramming.pub/introduction-to-waitress-a-wsgi-server-for-python-2-and-3-c77e20cb292b
- https://docs.pylonsproject.org/projects/waitress/en/stable/

_decoded_content.title: SIGTERM handling not compatible with Windows
_decoded_content.description:
As described in #2743, the SIGTERM handling is not currently supported on Windows.

Here is a possible explanation with workaround: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26061814/signal-handling-in-windows

_decoded_content.title: Migrate STDOUT/STDIN exchanges from asynchio pipes to queues
_decoded_content.description:
As discussed in #2743 and this comment (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2743#note_569087851), asyncio queues can be used in place of pipes to send data between processes.


cc @pandemicsyn 

--------------

From our code:

https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/c58cb8e56be1b8bae0eefcb6ba906e3c2010852e/src/meltano/core/logging/output_logger.py#L201

```python
   async def _read_from_fd(self, read_fd):
        # Since we're redirecting our own stdout and stderr output,
        # the line length limit can be arbitrarily large.
        line_length_limit = 1024 * 1024 * 1024  # 1 GiB

        reader = asyncio.StreamReader(limit=line_length_limit)
        read_protocol = asyncio.StreamReaderProtocol(reader)

        loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
        read_transport, _ = await loop.connect_read_pipe(  # <<<<
            lambda: read_protocol, os.fdopen(read_fd)
        )

        await capture_subprocess_output(reader, self)
```

From https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-platforms.html#windows:

> SelectorEventLoop has the following limitations:
> 
> - ...
> - Pipes are not supported, so the loop.connect_read_pipe() and loop.connect_write_pipe() methods are not implemented.

--------------

Alternative implementation using queues from [here](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2743#note_568237854):

```python
async def first_pipe_cmd(command, queue, cwd="."):
   proc = await asyncio.create_subprocess_shell(
           command,
           stdout=asyncio.subprocess.PIPE,
           #stderr=asyncio.subprocess.PIPE, 
           cwd=cwd)
  #await asyncio.wait(_outstream_handler(proc.stderr, "stderr", "first_pipe_cmd")) #Broken at the moment
   data ="first"
   while data:
       data = await proc.stdout.readline()
       line = data.decode()
       if data: await queue.put(line)
       logging.info(f"Queue data for processes, data is {line}")
   logging.info("First piped process has completed")
```

To replicate on windows

```

PS C:\code\meltano-windowstest2> meltano --log-level=debug elt tap-csv target-csv
```

Output from Meltano command (Note that the data in this instance actually does properly flow to my output file, but the program is stuck and I have to signal the process (CTRL+C) to stop the program, which then leads to the exceptions being dumped. Also note that I tried to dump the output to a log file instead of my command prompt output but that didn't include the exception information from asyncio (`>log 2>&1`) after the CTRL+C was sent so this is just a straight copy from my powershell window instead. 

The exceptions not being printed is probably caused by `loop.set_exception_handler` not being utilized. That could probably be a separate issue, and would help some folks with debugging asyncio. _decoded_content.title: Reported bug on Windows (docker): plugins available to select but are not available to run
_decoded_content.description:
A user has reported in slack and demoed in a screenshare session that after spinning up the docker container for the project, they were unable to execute a pipeline due a failure that the plugin was not installed. The user reported that if they go through the extra step of logging into the container via command line, and running `meltano install` again, the symptom would be resolved - at least until the process is repeated again on another workstation.

In our screenshare session, we tried a few different iterations and seemed to have luck by reording the commands within the project's `Dockerfile`. On comparison with this repo, that text did match what we have here.

We should attempt to reproduce this issue on our side and confirm if a similar adjustment in the Dockerfile resolves the symptom.

We should also open additional issues if there are improvements we can make in the available documentation.

Link to conversation in slack: https://meltano.slack.com/archives/CFG3C3C66/p1615923950017800?thread_ts=1615473028.130200&cid=CFG3C3C66

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

```
func(project, *args, **kwargs)
File "c:\users\none\appdata\local\programs\python\python36\lib\site-packages\meltano\cli\ui.py", line 66, in ui
asyncio.get_child_watcher()
File "c:\users\none\appdata\local\programs\python\python36\lib\asyncio\events.py", line 709, in get_child_watcher
return get_event_loop_policy().get_child_watcher()
File "c:\users\none\appdata\local\programs\python\python36\lib\asyncio\events.py", line 562, in get_child_watcher
raise NotImplementedError
NotImplementedError
```

You can see that they are running Windows, and that `asyncio.get_child_watcher` raises `NotImplementedError`.

This is consistent with [the documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-policy.html#asyncio.AbstractEventLoopPolicy.get_child_watcher) for that method, which states:

> This function is Unix specific.

Can we make this statement conditional on running on a Unix-like environment, or do we need to find an alternative implementation for Windows?

(Whether or not it makes sense to support Windows at this stage is a different topic, but for now let's assume we do.)
